instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot but 20V on usb-c
threads.message:
Hi,
i have this board very clean, no liquid, stop to work in use.
i have the 20V on usb-c, the current is cycling between 0,029A and 0,600A
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> =10,92V too low no? battery+power supply.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL>=3,39
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_T</SIGNAL>=3,36
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> missing not short
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL> missing not short
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL>=0V
i need help, is it <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> too low? or another thing?
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot but 20V on usb-c
threads.message:
ALWAYS check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> WITHOUT battery.
If battery is connected, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is automatically adjusted, accordingly with battery charge level.

Do you get SLPS2R voltages?
Try to put in DFU restore mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot but 20V on usb-c
threads.message:
i try to put in DFU but i have an error when i try to restore, i attach the message.
i have <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>=1,78V , <SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>=0,8V but not <SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>=0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot but 20V on usb-c
threads.message:
"not <SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>=0V"
There is a problem then.
Check diode mode to ground first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot but 20V on usb-c
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot but 20V on usb-c
threads.message:
Read more posts about DFU restore.
Many people complain, not easy to get it done so fast.
Try all the tricks they mentioned.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot but 20V on usb-c
threads.message: I try again in DFU with another macbook pro, i have always the same error.
